title-group.article-title: Generation COVID: Young Adult Substance Use

contrib-group.aff: Department of Psychology and Neuroscience, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Campus Box #3270, 235 E. Cameron Avenue, Chapel Hill, NC, USA 27599-3270

author-notes.corresp: ∗Corresponding author. , Campus Box #3270, Davie Hall, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC 27599-3270.

license.license-p: Since January 2020 Elsevier has created a COVID-19 resource centre with free information in English and Mandarin on the novel coronavirus COVID-19. The COVID-19 resource centre is hosted on Elsevier Connect, the company's public news and information website. Elsevier hereby grants permission to make all its COVID-19-related research that is available on the COVID-19 resource centre - including this research content - immediately available in PubMed Central and other publicly funded repositories, such as the WHO COVID database with rights for unrestricted research re-use and analyses in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for free by Elsevier for as long as the COVID-19 resource centre remains active.

abstract.p: Opposing theories posited that young adult substance use during the COVID-19 pandemic would decline due to restricted access and social engagement or increase due to efforts to cope with rising distress, loneliness, and isolation. Peer-reviewed global longitudinal studies found (a) overall declines in commonly used substances in 2020 with some rebounding in 2021; (b) individual differences in this pattern, with declines linked to factors limiting access and increases to pre-existing risk; and (c) under-developed evidence to evaluate increased coping-related use. Given potential links between surging mental health disorders and substance use, further surveillance and wider dissemination of substance use programming is needed, particularly for vulnerable individuals and settings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Young adulthood—sometimes recognized as a distinct developmental life stage also called emerging adulthood—is a time of increased risk behaviors, including substance use and related problems [1, 2]. These behaviors take place during a period of increasing identity exploration, instability (e.g., in relationships, work, residence), self-focus, and optimism [3]. The combination of autonomy-striving, social reorientation from family toward peers, and maturing cognitive functioning are often acknowledged contributors to elevated young adult risk behaviors [[4], [5], [6]]. Aligned with this view, the Monitoring the Future (MTF) Study—the largest epidemiological panel study of adolescent and young adult substance use in the United States (U.S.)— documents long-standing peaks for most forms of substance use between the ages of 18-25, corresponding to young adulthood [7].

One goal of such surveillance studies is to track historical and cohort perturbations in patterns of substance use, including those encompassing the COVID-19 pandemic. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on young adults encompasses not only disease exposure but also changes to micro- and macro-societal contexts related to social policy and practices [8]. For young adults who may have been more vulnerable to pandemic stress, closures and restrictions in higher education, the workplace, and public gathering spaces exemplify indirect pandemic effects [9, 10]. In several parts of the world, the pandemic coincided with heightened conflict around social justice and violence against marginalized populations, intensifying pandemic effects [11, 12]. Echoing studies around the globe, MTF reported elevated rates of anxiety and depression symptoms for young adults during the first year of the pandemic [10, 13].

Less attention, however, has focused on pandemic-linked changes in young adult substance use. At the beginning of the pandemic, opposing theories posit that substance use during the COVID-19 pandemic would (a) decline due to restricted access to substances and the social contexts in which use occurs or (b) increase due to efforts to cope with rising distress, loneliness, and isolation [13, 14]. Young adults, given their newly found mobility, peaking substance use, and intensifying social engagement, may have been vulnerable to both mechanisms [15].

In the current paper, we summarize global studies regarding changes in substance use and the COVID-19 pandemic and related stressors. Of necessity, any one method can confound developmental change in substance use (which is rapid during young adulthood), ongoing historic change (cohort and non-pandemic secular trends) and acute pandemic-linked change. Thus, we reviewed both cohort studies (comparing different age-matched young adults over years) and longitudinal studies (comparing the same young adults as they age over the years). All studies allowed pre-to-intra pandemic comparisons or directly assessed associations between pandemic stressors and substance use. Our goal was to discern how the first two years of the pandemic impacted young adult substance use.

sec.title: Overall Trends
sec.p: Nationally representative studies provide the most generalizable estimates of overall changes in young adult substance use associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, although such data have only been published for a handful of high-income countries. In the U.S., MTF showed drops in some forms of substance use early in the pandemic, with only a subset rebounding [[16], [17], [18]]. Of the most common substances, rates of binge drinking (5+ in a row) in the past two-week period dropped from 33% in 2019 (pre-pandemic) to 24% in 2020 (March-November), with a rebound to pre-pandemic levels at 30% in 2021. This deflection point, however, was only evident in college students, as a 10-year negative trend among non-college young adults continued steadily into the pandemic. Ten-year declines in cigarette use that preceded the pandemic for both college and non-college young adults showed non-significant increases among college students (from 4% in 2020 to 6% in 2021) and a large coinciding decrease in non-college youth (from 13% to 7%). Use of marijuana and other drugs in the past 30 days did not notably change. Thus, although the overall U.S. trend is for decreases in some forms of commonly used substances (i.e., alcohol and tobacco) with some rebounding, differences for college and noncollege young adults were evident.

Using a longitudinal design, Clare and colleagues similarly reported declines in alcohol-related harm in an Australian cohort assessed in the first months of the pandemic [19]. Trends in other national cohort studies, however, differed across drinking indicators. The Swiss Youth Epidemiological Study on Mental Health reported reductions in monthly binge drinking (6+ drinks for men and 4+ drinks for women) from 2018 to 2020 that were maintained in 2021; however, early declines in weekly binge drinking rebounded sooner, reaching pre-pandemic levels in 2021 [20]. Similarly, the United Kingdom (U.K.) Household Longitudinal Study reported increases in young adult binge drinking (6+ drinks weekly) and frequent drinking (4+ drinks weekly) into April 2020 whereas heavy drinking (5+ drinks on a typical day), cigarette use, and regular e-cigarette use all decreased relative to pre-COVID assessments. These findings were similar for young (18-24) and older adults (25-65+) and across gender and education level [21].

Thus, a pattern for decreased alcohol and cigarette use emerged in nationally representative samples, except for more frequent, heavy drinking that increased or more quickly rebounded in the Swiss and U.K. studies. As such, individuals with greater pre-pandemic substance use may have been less likely to pause and more quick to return to substance use as compared to their peers [20]. Moreover, patterns differed in U.S. college students and noncollege youth. Given the salience of individual differences in these trends, it is not surprising that findings from other longitudinal studies with less representative samples (which vary in what individual differences they capture) diverged in reports of young adults’ substance use over the pandemic.

Such studies report increases, no change, and decreases in pandemic substance use. For example, heavy drinking increased in the first year of the pandemic across cohorts of 18- to 20-year-olds completing annual health care screenings in California [22]. Yet, in a study in Ontario, Canada of pre-pandemic substance users, daily drinking quantity did not change as heavy drinking and alcohol-related consequences decreased, regardless of income status [23]. Few studies reported data post-2020. Still, the U.S. multi-site NCANDA study did find decreased past-month drinking from pre-pandemic averages in June and December 2020, but increased drinking days among drinkers in June 2020. Still, both returned to pre-pandemic levels by June 2021 [24]. Typical drinking quantity and binge drinking did not change in the NCANDA study, even among pre-pandemic binge drinkers, though financial adversity increased nicotine use.

Although still uncommon, recent longitudinal studies have begun to map factors accounting for individual differences in pandemic-related substance use in young adults. Findings showed that childhood maltreatment predicted self-reported increases in alcohol and cannabis use and greater COVID-related stressors predicted increased 30-day e-cigarette and marijuana use, but not changes in cigarette or alcohol use [[25]∗, [26]]. Among pre-pandemic substance users, pandemic changes in anxiety and depression were unrelated to changes in drinking, though alcohol-related problems decreased less for those with clinically significant increases in depression [23].

Together, these longitudinal studies suggest an overall drop in alcohol and tobacco use in the first year of the pandemic with a potential rebound (particularly for alcohol use) in the second year. However, this trend belies important individual differences potentially related to established pre-pandemic substance use and known risk factors such as adverse childhood experiences and depression.

sec.title: College Students
sec.p: College students form a unique group for change in substance use during the pandemic [27]. Although several studies examined changes in residential college students’ substance use, most used cross-sectional designs and retrospective recall or self-reported changes in rates of use [[28], [29], [30], [31]]. In contrast, Vasconcelos and colleagues assessed drinking during early lockdown (April-May 2020) and after lockdown restrictions were lifted (October 2020) in Portuguese students who reported regular binge drinking pre-lockdown [32]. Drinking fell faster among regular binge drinkers than infrequent ones, particularly among those who returned to family residences. The difference made the two groups indistinguishable after lockdown. Other studies from the U.S. show similar declines that were most pronounced in those under age 21 [33]. In addition, Sokolovsky and colleagues found that U.S. college students who entered the pandemic using nicotine were more likely to pause past-week tobacco use if they moved back with family, had less pandemic news exposure, and had fewer pre-existing nicotine dependence symptoms [34].

In contrast, a U.S. study oversampling 18-20 year olds who misused prescription drugs found increased alcohol and marijuana use within the first two months of the pandemic but reported no change in nicotine use or prescription drug misuse [35]. Increases in marijuana use were greatest for those with higher financial strain and marijuana craving, whereas nicotine use increased most among those with lower loneliness and higher financial strain. Together, these studies highlight the role of college campuses in providing access to substances and use-friendly contexts, particularly for those underage. They also highlight the role of other factors (news exposure, financial strain, loneliness, and prior substance use) that may similarly impact college and noncollege young adults.

sec.title: Socially Marginalized Young Adults in the United States
sec.p: Although discrimination and prejudice intensified for many marginalized young adults during the pandemic [10, 11], we found no longitudinal studies that assessed changes in substance use in these young adults relative to their peers. However, three studies noted changes within these young adults and provide a starting point for addressing potentially unique pandemic responses in these groups. For example, Hicks found non-linear changes in drinking such that rates of abstinence and high frequency drinking rose early in the pandemic and infrequent drinking fell [36]. These changes were similar across Black, Asian, and Hispanic/Latinx college students. Moving back to family decreased use, whereas prior trouble with the police and impulsivity increased use. Romano and Sanchez found increases in early pandemic drinking in a noncollege sample of young adult Latinos immigrating to the US, especially for those under 21 [37]. Lastly, though not assessing pre-pandemic change, a daily diary study of sexual/gender minority young adults found that COVID news exposure was unrelated to daily alcohol and marijuana use but did predict higher coping motives for both substances. In addition, participants with greater news exposure drank less but had higher coping motives for drinking [38]. Although more research is needed, initial studies point to complexity in understanding intersecting pandemic and marginalization experiences as impacting young adult substance use.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In general, longitudinal findings indicate that alcohol and tobacco use dropped following pandemic lockdown before rebounding for many young adults about one year later (similar to more inclusive reviews, [39]). This trend is both tentative (based on few studies) and qualified, hiding substantial variation in early responses to the pandemic across individuals and settings. Few studies report findings from 2021 or later, underlining the need for further research even as public concern about the pandemic has waned. Assessing long-term impact requires attention to how the developmental timing of pandemic experiences affect rising cohorts of young adults both in terms of normative early increases and later decreases in substance use during this life stage [40]. Importantly, we do not yet know whether the overall trajectory of young adulthood substance use has shifted over time, particularly for less commonly used substances.

Nonetheless, we offer the following early lessons from our summary. First, decreased access matters, particularly for underaged college youth. This finding reinforces efforts for greater uptake of empirically-supported programs that restrict availability of high-risk drinking contexts on campuses [41]. Second, individual differences are key to understanding the impact of the pandemic on young adult substance use. This is likely particularly true for understanding pandemic effects within socially marginalized communities for whom societal stressors were compounded [10, 11]. Third, links between the surging mental health crisis and substance use have yet to play out. Pandemic-primed elevations in anxiety, depression, and suicidality continue for young adults; all of which show pre-pandemic associations with substance use [42]. Because studies of mental health often do not assess substance use, we have yet to learn whether anticipated surges in substance use to cope with distress—including isolation and loneliness—are part of the current mental health crisis for your adults. Fourth, pharmacological interventions have increased with the mental health crisis [43, 44], many of which are contraindicated for alcohol and drug use. Thus, substance use may undermine such intervention or may carry greater physiological risks due to such co-use. Fifth and finally, more robust surveillance systems for young adult substance use are needed that include other health outcomes and separate developmental and historical change (e.g., accelerated longitudinal cohort designs).

sec.title: Declaration of Competing Interest
sec.p: The first author serves as the chair of the scientific advisory board for the NCANDA study, results from which are highlighted in this article. The authors declare no other competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this article.

element-citation.article-title: Alcohol use among young Australian adults in May-June 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic: A prospective cohort study
The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on young adults’ mental health in Switzerland: A longitudinal cohort study from 2018 to 2021
element-citation.source: Int J Env Res Public Heal

note.p: This longitudinal study in Switzerland reported changes in young adult substance use comparing pre- and during-pandemic timepoints. Participants (N=1175) had a mean age of 19.6 (61.4% female; 85.3% Swiss nationality; 66% German-speaking, 27.2% French-speaking, and 6.8% Italian-speaking). The study reported decreases in monthly binge drinking (6+ drinks for men and 4+ drinks for women) from 2018 to 2020 which were maintained in 2021. However, early declines in weekly binge drinking rebounded sooner, reaching pre-pandemic levels in 2021.

element-citation.article-title: Mental health and health behaviours before and during the initial phase of the COVID-19 lockdown: Longitudinal analyses of the UK Household Longitudinal Study

note.p: This longitudinal study (N=9748) of adults 18+ in the U.K. reported changes in young adult (n=3009, aged 18-24) substance use comparing pre- and during-pandemic timepoints. The study reported increases in binge drinking (6+ drinks weekly) and frequent drinking (4+ drinks weekly) into April 2020 whereas heavy drinking (5+ drinks on a typical day), current cigarettes use, and regular e-cigarette use all decreased relative to pre-pandemic assessments.

element-citation.article-title: Alcohol use among young adults in Northern California during the COVID-19 pandemic—An electronic health records-based study
COVID-19 impacts on drinking and mental health in emerging adults: Longitudinal changes and moderation by economic disruption and sex

note.p: This study (N=473) of young adults with a mean age of 23.8 (58.4% female; 70.4% White) found that young adults reported decreased heavy drinking (days with 3+ drinks for females and 4+ drinks for males) and adverse alcohol consequences during the pandemic.

element-citation.article-title: Did the acute impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on drinking or nicotine use persist? Evidence from a cohort of emerging adults followed for up to nine years

note.p: This U.S. multi-site NCANDA study (N=348) of young adults (49% female; 13% Hispanic; 68% White, 12% Black, 8% Alaskan Native or Pacific Islander, 7% Asian) found decreased past-month drinking from pre-pandemic averages in June and December 2020, but increased drinking days among drinkers in June 2020. Both returned to pre-pandemic levels by June 2021.

element-citation.article-title: Stressors and symptoms associated with a history of adverse childhood experiences among older adolescents and young adults during the COVID-19 pandemic in Manitoba, Canada
element-citation.source: Heal Promot Chronic Dis Prev Can

note.p: This study (N=664) of youth aged 16-21 found among young adults (n=401; aged 18-21; 57.8% female, 42.3% male) childhood maltreatment predicted self-reported increases in alcohol and cannabis use during the pandemic.

element-citation.article-title: COVID-related distress, mental health, and substance use in adolescents and young adults
Unpacking the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic: Identifying structural domains

The effects of sleep quality and resilience on perceived stress, dietary behaviors, and alcohol misuse: A mediation-moderation analysis of higher education students from Asia, Europe, and North America during the COVID-19 pandemic
Stimulant Norms and Prevalence (SNAP) Study Team. Alcohol use, cannabis use, and psychopathology symptoms among college students before and after COVID-19
Stressors experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic and substance use among US college students
Understanding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on stress, mood, and substance use among young adults in the greater Minneapolis-St. Paul area: Findings from project EAT
Effects of the COVID-19 mitigation measures on alcohol consumption and binge drinking in college students: A longitudinal survey
element-citation.source: Int J Env Res Public Heal

note.p: This study (N=146) of Portuguese college students with a mean age of 19.5 (81.0% female, 19.0% male) found drinking decreased during the pandemic among those that reported regular binge drinking pre-pandemic.

element-citation.article-title: What happens when the party moves home? The effect of the COVID-19 pandemic on U.S. college student alcohol consumption as a function of legal drinking status using longitudinal data
Preliminary impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on smoking and vaping in college students
Effect of COVID-19 disruptions on young adults’ affect and substance use in daily life
Divergent changes: Abstinence and higher-frequency substance use increase among racial/ethnic minority young adults during the COVID-19 global pandemic

note.p: This study (N=323) of racial/ethnic minority young adults in college (81.5% cisgender women; 36.1% Asian, 34.5% Black, 15.5% Hispanic/Latinx, 11.8% multi-racial) found that rates of abstinence and high frequency drinking rose early in the pandemic and infrequent drinking fell. Moving back to family decreased use and prior trouble with the police and impulsivity increased use.

element-citation.article-title: A characterization of pre- to post-immigration alcohol use among recent Latino immigrants to the United States before and during the COVID-19 pandemic
Doomscrolling: Prospective associations between daily COVID news exposure, internalizing symptoms, and substance use among sexual and gender minority individuals assigned female at birth

note.p: This daily diary study (N=429) of sexual/gender minority young adults assigned female at birth with a mean age of 22.3 (54.8% White, 30.1% Latinx, 23.8% Black, 12.4% Asian, 7.9% Other race/ethnicity) found that pandemic news exposure was unrelated to daily alcohol and marijuana use but did predict higher coping motives for both substances.

sec.title: Data availability
sec.p: No data was used for the research described in the article.
